The question asks for the marginal distribution of \( v_{14} \) given an interventional setting where \( v_7 \) is set to 1. This is an interventional query, and we need to compute the distribution of \( v_{14} \) under the interventional distribution \( P_{v_{14} | do(v_7 = 1)} \).

Since \( v_7 \) is intervened to be 1, we use the second row of the CPT for \( v_{14} \):

\[ P(v_{14} = 0 | do(v_7 = 1)) = 0.1 \]
\[ P(v_{14} = 1 | do(v_7 = 1)) = 0.9 \]

Thus, the marginal distribution of \( v_{14} \) given \( do(v_7 = 1) \) is:

\[ P(v_{14} = 0 | do(v_7 = 1)) = 0.1 \]
\[ P(v_{14} = 1 | do(v_7 = 1)) = 0.9 \]

   \[
   P(v_{10}=1, v_{11}=1, v_{12}=1, v_{13}=1, v_{14}=1) = P(v_{10}=1 | v_{3}, v_{12}) \cdot P(v_{11}=1 | v_{1}, v_{7}) \cdot P(v_{12}=1 | v_{13}, v_{6}) \cdot P(v_{13}=1 | v_{7}) \cdot P(v_{14}=1 | v_{6}) \cdot P(v_{3} | v_{2}) \cdot P(v_{2} | v_{1}) \cdot P(v_{7} | v_{0}, v_{1}) \cdot P(v_{1})
